subject: Art & Design
title: Japanese Architecture: Simplicity and Impermanence
description: A 60-second lesson on Japanese Architecture: Simplicity and Impermanence.

hook.text: The Ise Grand Shrine in Japan is rebuilt from scratch every 20 years. It's both ancient and brand new simultaneously.

buildup.text: Traditional Japanese architecture uses wood, paper screens (shoji), and modular tatami mats for flexible spaces.

discovery.text: The philosophy embraces impermanence (wabi-sabi). Buildings are meant to weather, age, and eventually return to nature.

twist.text: Western architecture fights decay. Japanese architecture accepts it. Two philosophies, two approaches to beauty.

climax.text: Tadao Ando and Kengo Kuma blend this tradition with modern concrete and glass â€” old philosophy, new materials.

punchline.text: Japanese architecture doesn't resist time. It flows with it.
